column2: Mid-2012 Population Estimates: Single year of age and sex for local authorities in the United Kingdom; estimated resident population.
Contents
Estimated resident population by single year of age group for constituent countries; counties; London boroughs and districts in England; unitary authorities in Wales; council areas within
Scotland and district council areas in Northern Ireland.
Notes and Definitions
1. It is ONS policy to publish population estimates rounded to at least the nearest hundred persons.  These unit-level estimates are provided to enable and encourage further calculations and
analysis.  However, the estimates cannot be guaranteed to be as exact as the level of detail implied by unit-level data.  We request that data are rounded to the nearest 100 if quoted in any
publication, documentation or similar.
2. The estimated resident population of an area includes all those people who usually live there, regardless of nationality.  Arriving international migrants are included in the usually resident
population if they remain in the UK for at least a year.  Emigrants are excluded if they remain outside the UK for at least a year.  This is consistent with the United Nations definition of a
long-term migrant.  Armed forces stationed outside of the UK are excluded.  Students are taken to be usually resident at their term time address.
3. At a subnational level, the population estimates reflect boundaries that were in place on 1 April of the reference year.
4. Codes are those used by ONS from 1 January 2011, in line with the UK coding and naming policy for statistical geographies.  A lookup for the previous codes is available via the
ONS Website
5. Local estimates are now calculated by single year of age; but these figures are less reliable and we advise that single year of age data for local areas should be aggregated to at least
five-year age groupings for use in further calculations, onwards circulation, or for presentation purposes. (Splitting into 0 year olds and 1-4 year olds is an acceptable exception).
6. Further advice on the appropriate use of these data can be obtained by emailing pop.info@ons.gsi.gov.uk or phoning 01329 444661 and asking to speak to a statistician.
